params.text:
INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT

Pest is managed by using various methods or tactics.  The process of minimizing the use of chemical pesticides is called integrated pest management (IPM). IPM methods are cultural, physical, mechanical, biological, and policy and regulations. Regular monitoring of the condition of the crop is a key to successful pest management. Knowledge on the pests is also an important aspect in identifying what method is the best to use.   

 

Insect Pest and Disease Management

Regular monitoring should be done to assess the performance of the crops if they are infested or infected. Pest management is the use of two or more methods to minimize the use of chemical pesticides. The common insect pests and diseases of pole sitao are presented as follows: 

 

Control measures for insect pests and diseases of pole sitao.

items.description:
PEST: Beanfly (Ophiomyia phaseoli)

 

DESCRIPTION: 

Very destructive during seedling stage. The adult is a minute jet black fly attacking the seedlings just after germination. Maggot feeds as miners working down the petiole into the stem by boring holes on the leaves. Severe damage leads to plant witling and drying-up.

 

CONTROL MEASURE:

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Use neem seeds (50g seeds/gallon of water).

  • Spray soap solution (4 tbsp. soap/16 li water).

  • Do not use infested seeds.

  • Spray insecticide whenever necessary.

PEST: Aphids (Aphids craccivora)

 

DESCRIPTION: 

Aphids occur in dense clusters on the surface of leaves by sucking the sap especially the tip of the vines. Severe damage leads to stunted growth and leaf curl. Active vector of viral diseases.

 

CONTROL MEASURE:

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Remove the infested plant parts immediately. 

  • Spray hot pepper extracts and soap solution (100g macerated hot pepper/16 li water)

  • Practice crop rotation.

  • Spray insecticide as needed.

PEST: Pod borer (Maruca vitrata)

 

DESCRIPTION: 

Larvae feed on flower buds and bores into the pods.

 

CONTROL MEASURE:

  • tomato and corn.

  • Use Trichogramma spp. parasitoid. 

  • Grow repellant crops such as marigold, basil, onion and citronella.

  • Spray insecticide as needed.

PEST: Leafminer (Liriomyza sp.)

 

DESCRIPTION:

They feed on the green inner portion of the leaves leaving white zigzag lines.

 

CONTROL MEASURE:

  • Use yellow trap with oil.

  • Intercrop with suitable vegetables such as eggplant and okra.

  • Spray insecticides as needed.

PEST: Leafhopper (Amrasca biguttula)

 

CONTROL MEASURE: 

  • Spray with soap solution.

  • Spray insecticide as needed.

params.text:
Common diseases of Pole Sitao

 

1. Mosaic virus

Commonly carried by aphids or plant lice.  Infected leaves have irregularly-shaped light green areas of various sizes. Photosynthetic activity is affected, hence, low yield and quality.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Control the aphids.

  • Use resistant varieties.

  • Do not use the seeds of the infected variety. 

  • Rogue and burn the infected plants.

  • Practice crop rotation.

 

2. FusaRium wilt/root rot, caused by Fusarium oxysporum

It is one of the most destructive of all root organisms in beans. The disease is prevalent after prolonged ran and water logged conditions. Infected roots have internal rotting and brown discoloration of the vascular tissue inside the stem followed by wilting, become yellow and eventually will die.

 

CONTROL MEASURE:

  • Practice crop rotation.

  • Use resistant varieties.

  • Plant in area with well-drained soils.

  • Spray fungicides following the recommended rate.

 

3. Rust, caused by Uromyces phaseoli

The leaves have small white spots or flecks on the underside as the fist symptom. After few days, the spots break open into rust-colored pustules, about pinhead size. After the pustules appear, entire leaf begins to turn yellow and later turns brown, dries up and falls off.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Use resistant varieties.

  • Prune infected plants.

 

WEED MANAGEMENT

Weeds are contributory to yield loss if not controlled early. Hand weed or off-bar as often as necessary at first week after emergence and hill-up on the third week. Perform spot hand weeding. Spray herbicide following the manufacturer’s recommendation as indicated on the label whenever necessary.
